utterances: You write that they kind of like to live in the shadows to make it look like someone else is in charge but they really hold the strings.
Right.
And one of them, Igor Sechin, kind of controls all the (unintelligible) documents that reach Vladimir Putin's desk.
He is sort of the gatekeeper, if you like.
And that's his official job, and his other brief, which is less advertised, he oversees the economy.
You write about the very strong anti-Western sentiment of the current KGB.
It almost sounds reminiscent of the Cold War.
What do you see as the future of the KGB in Russia?
It's a very good question.
There are two conflicting trends.
One is their psychology and their mentality is very much shaped by the Cold War.
And that's not going to change.
I didn't get any sense when reporting on this piece that any of them were prepared to take a view that the West is no longer an adversary of Russia.
So anti-NATO, anti-America, anti-West will very much continue to define this course, which these people bring.
Then on the conflicting side, there is - there is the economy.
These people have benefited from the market economy and they've benefited from capitalism.
And they're not about to get rid of it.
To what extend this first belief, the first sort of anti-Western beliefs will collide with the economic reality will be a very interesting test of their endurance.
Arkady Ostrovsky is the Moscow bureau chief for the Economist magazine.
Thank you so much for speaking with us.
Thank you.
This is DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
I'm Alex Cohen.
And I'm Madeleine Brand.
Earlier in the program we talked about race and language and the use of certain potentially offensive words; think the N-word, the B-word, the H-word.
Be advised you will hear those words in this upcoming segment.
What is okay to say, when, and by whom?
We heard earlier from some young people and from the senior editor of Ebony magazine.
And now we hear from Frances Callier and Angela Shelton, two comediennes who go by the conjoined name, Frangela.
There's no way around it.
The new anthem which replaced it, called ""Dideba,"" or ""Glory,"" wasn't actually new; it was used in Georgia before the country was annexed by the Soviets.
But ""Dideba"" never really caught on.
Many Georgians found the lyrics too complicated and they were full of bitter irony.
The opening verse described Georgia as a paradise on Earth, a far cry from the civil wars and economic collapse of the 1990s in Georgia.
The anthem also became associated with the increasingly corrupt and unpopular government, says journalist Giorgi Bardzulashuili(ph).
(Through Translator) Then, people were really leery of any initiatives which came from the government.
Even if the music for any new anthem had been really good, people might not have learned it anyway, just as a kind of protest against the authorities.
And there was another problem.
Dideba"" sounded strikingly similar to the anthem of another country, Germany.
Composer Vakhtang Kakhidze conducts Georgia's main symphony.
I didn't like this because first two or three bars, it's absolutely the same as German anthem, and that's why.
But when the new Georgian government took over power in 2003, it immediately chose a new flag and yet another new anthem.
(Soundbite of ""Liberty"")
Unidentified Choir #4: (Singing in foreign language)
Georgians would have been forgiven for anthem fatigue, but this newest new anthem, called ""Liberty,"" caught on like wildfire.
(Soundbite of ""Liberty"")
Unidentified Choir #4: (Singing in foreign language)
(Singing in foreign language)
The words are catchy and upbeat.
It's not uncommon to hear street musicians churning it out.
(Soundbite of ""Liberty"")
(Singing in foreign language)
Young kids are now taught the anthem in school.
Most now know it so well that it's not unusual to hear them singing it like a rock song.
Most of it is from Georgia's most famous opera, composed in 1923 by Georgia's most revered composer, Zakharia Paliashuili.
The patriotic story is about two young Georgian soldiers torn between fighting over a woman or fighting enemy invaders.
Conductor Vakhtang Kakhidze said the opera called ""Daisi,"" which means ""The Dawn,"" was an ideal musical and metaphorical match for the new anthem.
It was not difficult for people to learn this music because genetically, they have this inside.
It was not taught them a new thing that you start from the new.
Patriotic themes have been high on the agenda of the new Georgian government.
The country's leadership hopes the use of symbolism will help instill more national pride after Georgia's recent history of chaos, war and economic collapse.
Lawrence Sheets, NPR News, Tbilisi, Georgia.
NPR's DAY TO DAY continues.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
When news broke early Saturday morning that Fidel Castro was dead, Cuban-Americans throughout Miami headed to a familiar spot.
The Versailles Restaurant is the heart of the Cuban exile community.
It's where Cuban-Americans talk politics and politicians seek their votes.
NPR's Greg Allen paid a visit.
(SOUNDBITE OF CAR HONKING)
Outside the Versailles Restaurant on the edge of Miami's Little Havana, it was still a busy scene yesterday, three days after Fidel Castro's death.
Miguel Villalobos was outside the restaurant early Saturday morning enjoying coffee with friends when he heard the news.
I happened to be here and it start coming, people - more people start coming and coming and coming.
Before I knew it, the whole thing was packed and they closed the street.
Villalobos is retired now, part of that first wave of Cuban exiles who've been frequenting the restaurant since it opened.
Yesterday, he was back with his daughter and two of his grandchildren.
He was wearing a cap that said Cuba Volveremos - Cuba will be back.
(SOUNDBITE OF CAR HONKING)
Inside, the walls of the restaurant are lined with mirrors, a nod to the French palace that gave the Versailles its name.
Servers all wore T-shirts saying Viva Cuba Libre.
The food is good, but the reason many Cuban-Americans come here is for conversation and company.
Luly Valls is one of the managers.
Her grandfather opened the restaurant in 1971.
We say it's la casa de exilio, which is like the home of the exiled people, you know?
So people come here to share stories, to laugh, to cry, to remember Cuba, too.
Anything political, anything happy, sad - it's like they're home, you know?
(CROSSTALK)
As at many Cuban restaurants, outside is where the action is.
Customers line up at the restaurant's ventanita, the coffee window, from early in the morning until early the next morning.
Frank Cantero is a businessman who starts his day at Versailles, often running into his own customers there.
It's the meeting place, and there's - I mean, groups of people congregate here specifically, Cuban, Cuban-Americans, and there's waves of them, right?
There's, like, a 7 o'clock group.
There's 7:30 in the morning group, an 8 o'clock group and, you know - and it's been passed on from generation to generation.
Well over a thousand people thronged the street outside the Versailles in the early morning hours Saturday after word got out that Fidel Castro had passed on.
But big crowds aren't unusual here.
Large numbers gathered on earlier occasions when rumors of Castro's death proved unfounded.
And Cantero says he's been here for several political campaign events.
Political figures need to make the stop here.
They'll kick off a candidacy here.
Jeb Bush started about, you know, a year and a half ago, you know, about his presidential run.
Trump was here just a couple of months ago.
The Versailles is neutral politically, hosting Democratic and Republican politicians alike.
Sometimes, Luly Valls says, with little or no notice.
When Trump came by recently, we had no idea.
He went into the bakery.
I spoke to the staff and some of the customers that were there and they said he was very polite, very nice, drank coffee, said it was very strong (laughter).
The price of gas is well below what it was a few years ago.
That's mostly because of hydraulic fracturing technology that reaches more gas reserves, and also because of a weak economy that's lowered demand for electricity.
And there's plenty more gas to come.
Yesterday, a study from the University of Texas confirmed government estimates of huge reserves in Texas alone.
That would suggest that coal is doomed, but not so fast.
The gas market is quirky.
As people started burning more gas, gas prices have crept up.
As natural gas prices have started to increase over the past few months, coal's share of U.S.
power generation has increased right alongside it.
